text: today on the caucus as President Obama
wraps up his rural economic tour
photographer Doug Mills on the mood of
the trip also Michael sheer on the
candidates rides call it the battle of
the busses the mood for the last two
days traveling with the president has
been pretty upbeat I mean jumping from
one event to another getting ice cream
getting popcorn he's obviously happy to
be out of Washington you can really see
it in his step around the White House
for the last month or so it's just been
like a clouds hanging over the building
it really felt kind of gloom and doom
and then you come out here on the road
people are talking about the jobs just
hundreds and hundreds of people along
the side of the road ninety percent of
what we've seen so far has been positive
and even when you roll into town and
they don't realize maybe that the
president made a surprise stop in their
town and come out of the woodwork we
have come across you know I don't know
if you'd call them protester penny would
see signs saying Obamacare we need more
jobs you're not doing your job it's
definitely been more positive than
negative and I think the photos that
I've been taking have shown that you
know I've tried to do both sides
out here in the heartland he is going
after the republicans and my attitude is
get it done and if they don't get it
done then we'll be running against a
congress that's not doing anything from
the american people and it the choice
will be very stark and will be very
clear this this bus trip feels a lot
like his bus trips back in two thousand
eight I was I was on the campaign then
and I saw at a very upbeat senator at
the time most of the presidential trips
you see him in a very presidential mode
a lot of speaking from behind a podium
he's wearing a suit it's very serious
stuff out here he just seems like his
sleeves were let down he's not wearing a
tie you hear the same music you did in
2008 crowds are big supportive there's
just you know definitely a different
energy level
the 2012 presidential campaign has
kicked into full gear well low gear
actually the battle of the buses is well
underway with each candidate trying to
outdo the others with big flashy
tricked-out motor coaches the newest bus
on the trail has the word Perry in huge
letters across both sides the Texas
governor called it an awesome big ol
motor coach as he boarded it monday for
a three-day swing across Iowa and he's
far from the only candidate with a bus
the picture of Herman Cain's face is as
big as well as big as a bus mrs.
Bachmann decided to go with repetition
for her bus her last name appears 24
times a 10 on each side and twice on the
front and back sometimes the lack of a
bus can be a sign of trouble tim
Pawlenty s bus broke down in Iowa before
the straw poll leaving him with a
brown-and-white Winnebago he of course
dropped out of the contest over the
weekend and the closest thing fattiest
McCotter the Michigan congressman and
presidential candidate had to a bus was
an ice cream van covered with cardboard
posters he came in dead last in the
straw poll this weekend with just 35
votes and finally there's President
Obama who is using a black Secret
Service bus for his three-day rural
economic tour this week it might as well
be dubbed the Intimidator I was driving
down those little towns in my big bus
and I'm we slowed down and I'm standing
in the front and I'm waving
what do all these buses have in common
none of them are open to the press
reporters must follow along behind the
bus this was not the case in 2007 in
1999 for that matter when Senator John
McCain straight talk express was on the
road talked us all out I mean you've
talked us all out all right for now as
the presidential candidates crisscross
swing states this year all we get is a
glimpse from the outside
